title: Lawsuit challenges sediment removal program
body: Los Angeles County Supervisors approve a program to remove 2.4 million cubic yards of sediment from the Devil's Gate Dam basin. The plan also would destroy more than 50 acres of wetland habitat. The Arroyo Seco Foundation and Pasadena Audubon file a lawsuit challenging the program.

title: County denied permit to remove sediment
body: Permit for sediment removal program at Devil's Gate Dam is rejected as levels in the basin reach 3.89 million cubic yards.

title: Station Fire impact felt
body: More than 936,000 cubic yards of sediment have been deposited in the reservoir since the 2009 Station Fire. The county flood control board announces plans to remove 1.67 million cubic yards of sediment.
source: Los Angeles County Flood Control District summary of Devil’s Gate Dam and Reservoir Design Standard and History

title: Station Fire burns Angeles National Forest
body: The Station Fire burns burns nearly the entire undeveloped watershed tributary to the dam. All told, the fire burns more than 160,000 acres — about 250 square miles — in the Angeles National Forest. Two firefighters are killed and scores of houses are destroyed.
source: Los Angeles County Flood Control District summary of Devil’s Gate Dam and Reservoir Design Standard and History

title: $10 million spent on earthquake retrofit and rehabilitation
body: Devil's Gate Dam undergoes earthquake retrofit and rehabilitation by County of Los Angeles. The $10 million project includes the contruction of a concrete buttress on the downstream face to increase the dam’s resistance to seismic forces, expands the spillway and grouts and buttresses the dam to current standards.
source: Los Angeles County Flood Control District summary of Devil’s Gate Dam and Reservoir Design Standard and History

title: Devil's Gate declared unsafe after seismic review
body: Following a seismic review, Devil's Gate Dam is declared unsafe due to the Sylmar earthquake. An operational restriction is placed on the dam.

title: Sylmar Earthquake
body: A 6.6 magnitude earthquake near Sylmar strikes on a fault beneath the San Gabriel Mountains. It is the largest in some 80 years. The earthquake leaves 64 people dead and injuries more than 2,500.

title: Cloudburst Fire
body: The Cloudburst Fire burns 27 acres of watershed above the dam. An additional 900,000 cubic yards of sediment is deposited in the reservoir.
source: Los Angeles County Flood Control District summary of Devil’s Gate Dam and Reservoir Design Standard and History

title: Spreading grounds created
body: The Los Angeles County Department of Public Works constructs about 13 acres of spreading grounds and a two-acre overflow basin at Devil's Gate Dam.

title: County changes course on name change
body: Los Angeles County moves to change Devil's Gate Dam to James W. Reagan Dam but relents in the face of objections. Later that year, a $15,000 project to build out a sliding gate is completed. The sluiceway will be opened to pass 1.6 million cubic yards of silt and debris to restore reservoir capacity back to 5,000 acre feet.

title: Newspaper: Build up of sediment poses hazard
body: A Pasadena Star-News editorial comments on the build-up of sediment behind dams, including the Devil's Gate. Writes the newspaper: "Even the layman recognizes that accumulated silt behind Southern California dams represents one of the greatest of flood threats. Decreasing ability of these barriers to impound storm waters is revealed in almost every protracted downpour." Later that year, a 60-foot tunnel is bored through Devil's Gate Dam to release sediment from the reservoir.

title: Major storm floods the Arroyo Seco
body: A March storm delivers an intense rainfall greater than a 50-year event. It deposits about 1.7 million cubic yards of sediment in the Devil's Gate Dam reservoir.

title: Plan introduced to channelize Arroyo Seco from Devil's Gate Dam to the Los Angeles River
body: The Los Angeles County Flood Control District develops a comprehensive $100 million flood control program consisting of channelization of the major streams and the construction of debris basins in the foothills. This plan includes channelizing the Arroyo stream from Devil's Gate Dam to the Los Angeles River.

title: Storms carry sediment into reservoir
body: The Brown Mountain Fire burns 3,550 acres in the watershed above the dam. About 800,000 cubic yards of sediment is deposited into the reservoir.
source: Los Angeles County Flood Control District summary of Devil’s Gate Dam and Reservoir Design Standard and History

title: Devil's Gate Dam dedicated
body: At a cost of $483,000 a completed Devil's Gate Dam is dedicated in June. It's the first dam built by the Los Angeles County Flood Control District.

title: Bond issued for construction of Devil's Gate Dam
body: Construction of Devil's Gate Dam passes as a Los Angeles County Flood Control Bond Issue.

title: Land for dam set aside
body: Following a major flood along the Arroyo Seco, Pasadena gives Los Angeles County an easement to be used for a dam.
